comment: I found a nice quote that seems to sum it up.

diff.*:
Line 6: Line 6:         −
'''Ethics''' studies questions pertaining to [[rights|right]] and [[wrong]], [[goodness|good]] and [[evil|bad]]. There is some tension between the notion of ethics as ''seeing'', and ethics as ''doing'' or solving disputes between those who are doing different things that aren't compatible.
+
'''Ethics''' the philosophical field which attempts to determine what is good, both for the individual and for the society as a whole.
  +   +
Dr. Jennifer P. Tanabe, author of ''[[Contemplating Unification Thought]]'', writes:
  +
:The goal of a theory of ethics is to determine what is good, both for the individual and for the society as a whole. Philosophers have taken different positions in defining what is good, on how to deal with conflicting priorities of individuals versus the whole, over the universality of ethical principles versus "situation ethics" in which what is right depends upon the circumstances rather than on some general law, and over whether goodness is determined by the results of the action or the means by which results are achieved.
  +   +
Thus ethics studies questions pertaining to [[rights|right]] and [[wrong]], [[goodness|good]] and [[evil|bad]]. This includes exploring the tension between the notion of ethics as ''seeing'', and ethics as ''doing'', as well as analyzing disputes between those who are doing different things that aren't compatible.
     
For the most accepted Western academic categorization of ethics, see [[moral philosophy]]. This article is concerned with that, analytic, approach, but also with the many other ways in which human beings define, limit and resolve conflicts.
 
For the most accepted Western academic categorization of ethics, see [[moral philosophy]]. This article is concerned with that, analytic, approach, but also with the many other ways in which human beings define, limit and resolve conflicts.
